sentences: Randolph Denard Ornette Coleman (March 9, 1930 – June 11, 2015) was an American jazz saxophonist, violinist, trumpeter, and composer known as a principal founder of the free jazz genre, a term derived from his 1960 album Free Jazz: A Collective Improvisation.
section: N/A

sentences: His pioneering performances often abandoned the chordal and harmony-based structure found in bebop, instead emphasizing a jarring and avant-garde approach to improvisation.
section: N/A

sentences: Born in Fort Worth, Texas, Coleman began his musical career playing in local R&B and bebop groups, and eventually formed his own group in Los Angeles featuring members such as Ed Blackwell, Don Cherry, Charlie Haden, and Billy Higgins.
section: N/A

sentences: In 1959, he released the controversial album The Shape of Jazz to Come and began a long residency at the Five Spot jazz club in New York City.
section: N/A

sentences: His 1960 album Free Jazz would profoundly influence the direction of jazz in that decade.
section: N/A

sentences: Beginning in the mid-1970s, Coleman formed the group Prime Time and explored funk and his concept of Harmolodic music.
section: N/A

sentences: Coleman's "Broadway Blues" and "Lonely Woman" became genre standards and are cited as important early works in free jazz.
section: N/A

sentences: His album Sound Grammar received the 2007 Pulitzer Prize for Music.
section: N/A

sentences: AllMusic called him "one of the most important (and controversial) innovators of the jazz avant-garde".
section: N/A
== Biography ==

sentences: Biography ==
section: == Biography ==
== Biography == | === Early life ===

sentences: Early life =
section: == Biography == | === Early life ===
== Biography == | === Early life ===

sentences: Coleman was born on March 9, 1930, in Fort Worth, Texas, where he was raised.
section: == Biography == | === Early life ===

sentences: He attended I.M. Terrell High School, where he participated in band until he was dismissed for improvising during "The Washington Post" march.
section: == Biography == | === Early life ===

sentences: He began performing R&B and bebop on tenor saxophone and started The Jam Jivers with Prince Lasha and Charles Moffett.
section: == Biography == | === Early life ===

sentences: Eager to leave town, he accepted a job in 1949 with a Silas Green from New Orleans traveling show and then with touring rhythm and blues shows.
section: == Biography == | === Early life ===

sentences: After a show in Baton Rouge, Louisiana, he was assaulted and his saxophone was destroyed.
section: == Biography == | === Early life ===

sentences: He switched to alto saxophone, which remained his primary instrument, first playing it in New Orleans after the Baton Rouge incident.
section: == Biography == | === Early life ===

sentences: He then joined the band of Pee Wee Crayton and traveled with them to Los Angeles.
section: == Biography == | === Early life ===

sentences: He worked at various jobs, including as an elevator operator, while pursuing his music career.
section: == Biography == | === Early life ===

sentences: In California he found like-minded musicians such as Ed Blackwell, Bobby Bradford, Don Cherry, Charlie Haden, Billy Higgins, and Charles Moffett.
section: == Biography == | === Early life ===

sentences: He recorded his debut album, Something Else!!!!
section: == Biography == | === Early life ===

sentences: (1958), with Cherry, Higgins, Walter Norris, and Don Payne.
section: == Biography == | === Early life ===

sentences: During the same year he belonged briefly to a quintet led by Paul Bley that performed at a club in New York City.
section: == Biography == | === Early life ===

sentences: By the time Tomorrow Is the Question! was recorded soon after with Cherry, Higgins, and Haden, the jazz world had been shaken up by Coleman's alien music.
section: == Biography == | === Early life ===

sentences: Some jazz musicians called him a fraud, while conductor Leonard Bernstein praised him.
section: == Biography == | === Early life ===
== Biography == | === 1959: The Shape of Jazz to Come ===
== Biography == | === 1959: The Shape of Jazz to Come ===

sentences: The Shape of Jazz to Come =
section: == Biography == | === 1959: The Shape of Jazz to Come ===
== Biography == | === 1959: The Shape of Jazz to Come ===

sentences: In 1959 Atlantic released The Shape of Jazz to Come.
section: == Biography == | === 1959: The Shape of Jazz to Come ===

sentences: According to music critic Steve Huey, the album "was a watershed event in the genesis of avant-garde jazz, profoundly steering its future course and throwing down a gauntlet that some still haven't come to grips with."
section: == Biography == | === 1959: The Shape of Jazz to Come ===

sentences: Jazzwise listed it No. 3 on their list of the 100 best jazz albums of all time.
section: == Biography == | === 1959: The Shape of Jazz to Come ===

sentences: When French philosopher Jacques Derrida interviewed him, Ornette said that "Lonely Woman" from the album resulted from seeing a rich woman who was in such solitude.
section: == Biography == | === 1959: The Shape of Jazz to Come ===

sentences: Coleman's quartet received a long – and sometimes controversial – engagement at Five Spot jazz club in New York City.
section: == Biography == | === 1959: The Shape of Jazz to Come ===

sentences: Leonard Bernstein, Lionel Hampton, and Modern Jazz Quartet were impressed and offered encouragement.
section: == Biography == | === 1959: The Shape of Jazz to Come ===

sentences: Hampton asked to perform with the quartet; Bernstein helped Haden obtain a composition grant from the John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation.
section: == Biography == | === 1959: The Shape of Jazz to Come ===

sentences: But trumpeter Miles Davis said Coleman was "all screwed up inside", although he later became a proponent of Coleman's innovations.
section: == Biography == | === 1959: The Shape of Jazz to Come ===

sentences: Coleman's early sound was due in part to his use of a plastic saxophone.
section: == Biography == | === 1959: The Shape of Jazz to Come ===

sentences: He bought a plastic horn in Los Angeles in 1954 because he was unable to afford a metal saxophone, though he didn't like the sound of the plastic instrument at first.
section: == Biography == | === 1959: The Shape of Jazz to Come ===

sentences: On the Atlantic recordings, Coleman's sidemen in the quartet are Cherry on cornet or pocket trumpet; Charlie Haden, Scott LaFaro, and then Jimmy Garrison on bass; and Higgins or his replacement Ed Blackwell on drums.
section: == Biography == | === 1959: The Shape of Jazz to Come ===

sentences: The complete recordings for the label were collected on the box set Beauty Is a Rare Thing.
section: == Biography == | === 1959: The Shape of Jazz to Come ===
== Biography == | === 1960s: Free Jazz and Blue Note ===

sentences: Free Jazz and Blue Note
section: == Biography == | === 1960s: Free Jazz and Blue Note ===
== Biography == | === 1960s: Free Jazz and Blue Note ===

sentences: In 1960, Coleman recorded Free Jazz: A Collective Improvisation, which featured a double quartet, including Don Cherry and Freddie Hubbard on trumpet, Eric Dolphy on bass clarinet, Haden and LaFaro on bass, and both Higgins and Blackwell on drums.
section: == Biography == | === 1960s: Free Jazz and Blue Note ===

sentences: The album was recorded in stereo with a reed/brass/bass/drums quartet isolated in each stereo channel.
section: == Biography == | === 1960s: Free Jazz and Blue Note ===

sentences: Free Jazz was, at nearly 40 minutes, the longest recorded continuous jazz performance to date and was one of Coleman's most controversial albums.
section: == Biography == | === 1960s: Free Jazz and Blue Note ===

sentences: The music features a regular but complex pulse, one drummer playing "straight" while the other played double-time; the thematic material is a series of brief, dissonant fanfares.
section: == Biography == | === 1960s: Free Jazz and Blue Note ===

sentences: A series of solo features for each member of the band, but the other soloists are free to chime in as they wish.
section: == Biography == | === 1960s: Free Jazz and Blue Note ===

sentences: In the January 18, 1962 issue of Down Beat magazine, in a review titled "Double View of a Double Quartet", Pete Welding gave the album five stars while John A. Tynan rated it zero stars.
section: == Biography == | === 1960s: Free Jazz and Blue Note ===

sentences: Time has been kinder to the album, though, with AllMusic listing it as one of "20 Essential Free Jazz albums".
section: == Biography == | === 1960s: Free Jazz and Blue Note ===

sentences: Coleman intended "free jazz" as simply an album title.
section: == Biography == | === 1960s: Free Jazz and Blue Note ===

sentences: But his growing reputation placed him at the forefront of jazz innovation, and free jazz was soon considered a new genre, though Coleman has expressed discomfort with the term.
section: == Biography == | === 1960s: Free Jazz and Blue Note ===

sentences: Among the reasons he may have disapproved of the term is that his music contains composition.
section: == Biography == | === 1960s: Free Jazz and Blue Note ===

sentences: His melodic material, although skeletal, recalls melodies that Charlie Parker wrote over standard harmonies.
section: == Biography == | === 1960s: Free Jazz and Blue Note ===

sentences: The music is closer to the bebop that came before it than is sometimes popularly imagined.
section: == Biography == | === 1960s: Free Jazz and Blue Note ===

sentences: After the Atlantic period and into the early part of the 1960s, Coleman's music became more angular and engaged with the avant-garde jazz which had developed in part around his innovations.
section: == Biography == | === 1960s: Free Jazz and Blue Note ===

sentences: After his quartet disbanded, he formed a trio with David Izenzon on bass and Charles Moffett on drums.
section: == Biography == | === 1960s: Free Jazz and Blue Note ===

sentences: He extended the sound of his music, introducing string players and playing trumpet and violin, which he played left-handed.
section: == Biography == | === 1960s: Free Jazz and Blue Note ===

sentences: He had little conventional musical technique and used the instruments to make large, unrestrained gestures.
section: == Biography == | === 1960s: Free Jazz and Blue Note ===

sentences: His friendship with Albert Ayler influenced his development on trumpet and violin.
section: == Biography == | === 1960s: Free Jazz and Blue Note ===

sentences: Charlie Haden sometimes joined this trio to form a two-bass quartet.
section: == Biography == | === 1960s: Free Jazz and Blue Note ===

sentences: Coleman signed with Blue Note and recorded At the Golden Circle Stockholm.
section: == Biography == | === 1960s: Free Jazz and Blue Note ===

sentences: In 1966, he recorded The Empty Foxhole with his son, Denardo Coleman, who was ten years old.
section: == Biography == | === 1960s: Free Jazz and Blue Note ===

sentences: Freddie Hubbard and Shelly Manne regarded this as an ill-advised piece of publicity on Coleman's part.
section: == Biography == | === 1960s: Free Jazz and Blue Note ===

sentences: Despite his youth, Denardo Coleman had studied drumming for several years.
section: == Biography == | === 1960s: Free Jazz and Blue Note ===

sentences: His technique was unrefined but enthusiastic, owing more to pulse-oriented free jazz drummers like Sunny Murray than to bebop drummers.
section: == Biography == | === 1960s: Free Jazz and Blue Note ===

sentences: He became his father's primary drummer in the late 1970s.
section: == Biography == | === 1960s: Free Jazz and Blue Note ===

sentences: Coleman formed another quartet.
section: == Biography == | === 1960s: Free Jazz and Blue Note ===

sentences: Haden, Garrison, and Elvin Jones appeared, and Dewey Redman joined the group, usually on tenor saxophone.
section: == Biography == | === 1960s: Free Jazz and Blue Note ===

sentences: On February 29, 1968 in a group with Haden, Ed Blackwell, and David Izenzon Coleman performed live with Yoko Ono at Albert Hall.
section: == Biography == | === 1960s: Free Jazz and Blue Note ===

sentences: One song was included on the album Yoko Ono/Plastic Ono Band (1970).
section: == Biography == | === 1960s: Free Jazz and Blue Note ===

sentences: He continued to explore his interest in string textures – from Town Hall, 1962, culminating with the Skies of America album in 1972.
section: == Biography == | === 1960s: Free Jazz and Blue Note ===

sentences: (Sometimes this had a practical value, as it facilitated his group's appearance in the UK in 1965, where jazz musicians were under a quota arrangement but classical performers were exempt.)
section: == Biography == | === 1960s: Free Jazz and Blue Note ===

sentences: === 1970s–1990s: Harmolodic funk and Prime Time =
section: == Biography == | === 1970s–1990s: Harmolodic funk and Prime Time ===
== Biography == | === 1970s–1990s: Harmolodic funk and Prime Time ===

sentences: Coleman, like Miles Davis before him, took to playing with electrified instruments.
section: == Biography == | === 1970s–1990s: Harmolodic funk and Prime Time ===

sentences: The 1976 funk album Dancing in Your Head, Coleman's first recording with the group which later became known as Prime Time, prominently featured electric guitars.
section: == Biography == | === 1970s–1990s: Harmolodic funk and Prime Time ===

sentences: While this marked a stylistic departure for Coleman, the music maintained certain similarities to his earlier work.
section: == Biography == | === 1970s–1990s: Harmolodic funk and Prime Time ===

sentences: These performances had the same angular melodies and simultaneous group improvisations – what Joe Zawinul referred to as "nobody solos, everybody solos" and what Coleman called harmolodics – and although the nature of the pulse was altered, Coleman's rhythmic approach was not.
section: == Biography == | === 1970s–1990s: Harmolodic funk and Prime Time ===

sentences: In the 1980s, albums such as Virgin Beauty and Of Human Feelings continued to use rock and funk rhythms, sometimes called free funk.
section: == Biography == | === 1970s–1990s: Harmolodic funk and Prime Time ===

sentences: Jerry Garcia played guitar on three tracks from Coleman's 1988 album Virgin Beauty: "Three Wishes", "Singing in the Shower", and "Desert Players".
section: == Biography == | === 1970s–1990s: Harmolodic funk and Prime Time ===

sentences: Coleman joined the Grateful Dead on stage in 1993 during "Space" and stayed for "The Other One", "Stella Blue", Bobby Bland's "Turn on Your Lovelight", and the encore "Brokedown Palace".
section: == Biography == | === 1970s–1990s: Harmolodic funk and Prime Time ===

sentences: Another collaboration was with guitarist Pat Metheny, with whom Coleman recorded Song X (1985); though the album was released under Metheny's name, Coleman was essentially co-leader (contributing all the compositions).
section: == Biography == | === 1970s–1990s: Harmolodic funk and Prime Time ===

sentences: In 1990, the city of Reggio Emilia in Italy held a three-day "Portrait of the Artist" featuring a Coleman quartet with Cherry, Haden, and Higgins.
section: == Biography == | === 1970s–1990s: Harmolodic funk and Prime Time ===

sentences: The festival also presented performances of his chamber music and the symphonic Skies of America.
section: == Biography == | === 1970s–1990s: Harmolodic funk and Prime Time ===

sentences: In 1991, Coleman played on the soundtrack for David Cronenberg's film Naked Lunch; the orchestra was conducted by Howard Shore.
section: == Biography == | === 1970s–1990s: Harmolodic funk and Prime Time ===

sentences: It is notable among other things for including a rare sighting of Coleman playing a jazz standard: Thelonious Monk's "Misterioso".
section: == Biography == | === 1970s–1990s: Harmolodic funk and Prime Time ===

sentences: Two 1972 (pre-electric)
section: == Biography == | === 1970s–1990s: Harmolodic funk and Prime Time ===

sentences: Coleman recordings, "Happy House" and "Foreigner in a Free Land", were used in Gus Van Sant's 2000 Finding Forrester.
section: == Biography == | === 1970s–1990s: Harmolodic funk and Prime Time ===

sentences: Coleman released four records in 1995 and 1996, and for the first time in many years worked regularly with piano players (either Geri Allen or Joachim Kühn).
section: == Biography == | === 1970s–1990s: Harmolodic funk and Prime Time ===
== Biography == | === 2000s ===
== Biography == | === 2000s ===

sentences: In September 2006 he released a live album titled Sound Grammar with his son, Denardo Coleman, and two bassists, Greg Cohen, and Tony Falanga.
section: == Biography == | === 2000s ===

sentences: This was his first album of new material in ten years and was recorded in Germany in 2005.
section: == Biography == | === 2000s ===

sentences: It won the 2007 Pulitzer Prize for music, Coleman being only the second jazz musician to win the prize.
section: == Biography == | === 2000s ===

sentences: Jazz pianist Joanne Brackeen stated in an interview with Marian McPartland that Coleman mentored her and gave her music lessons.
section: == Biography == | === 2000s ===

sentences: Personal life, death, and subsequent material loss ==
section: == Personal life, death, and subsequent material loss ==

sentences: Coleman married poet Jayne Cortez in 1954.
section: == Personal life, death, and subsequent material loss ==

sentences: The couple divorced in 1964.
section: == Personal life, death, and subsequent material loss ==

sentences: They had one son, Denardo, born in 1956.
section: == Personal life, death, and subsequent material loss ==

sentences: Coleman died of a cardiac arrest at the age of 85 in New York City on June 11, 2015.
section: == Personal life, death, and subsequent material loss ==

sentences: His funeral was a three-hour event with performances and speeches by several of his collaborators and contemporaries.
section: == Personal life, death, and subsequent material loss ==

sentences: Ornette Coleman was among hundreds of artists whose material was reportedly destroyed in the 2008 Universal fire.
section: == Personal life, death, and subsequent material loss ==

sentences: Coleman was dyslexic.
